nova.guidance: By default, designated except scheduler, filter, drivers, API extensions and networking.
nova.comment: All code except driver/plugins listed.  Even for replaceable drivers or plugins, we still expect use of the existing nova service that wraps those interfaces.

filter scheduler driver.description: (Host and cell)  While the line above implies the entire driver is fair game, this case is incredibly common and worth mentioning specifically.

keystone.guidance: Designation is outlined per API grouping. Identity (user and group) management APIs will not be designated. API access (with exception of auth) may be prohibited by policy (resulting in HTTP 403). Designated APIs include both v2.0 and v3 versions where applicable.
keystone.comment: Specific Drivers/Plugins and Identity management code are not designated as many deployments have custom drivers and/or read-only, federated, or externally managed Identity information.

assignment API.description: APIs for managing roles and assignment of roles to user(s)/group(s) for a given scope
assignment API.comment: Some functionality for v2.0 is provided via the 'admin_crud' extension

auth (v2.0) API.description: '/v2.0/tokens' APIs used for v2.0 authentication and token validation/revocation/signing certificates (when PKI tokens are in use)
auth (v2.0) API.comment: This includes the catalog data provided as part of the token body.

auth (v3) API.description: '/v3/auth' APIs used for v3 authentication and token validation/revocation
auth (v3) API.comment: This includes the catalog data provided as part of the token body and '/v3/auth/catalog'.

catalog API.description: APIs for managing services, endpoints, and regions
catalog API.comment: Catalog API is not designated due to the support of template catalog driver which cannot be updated via REST calls. The catalog in the token is considered part of the AUTH APIs.

drivers.description: specific implementations for the keystone API backends (e.g. SQL, LDAP, etc)

ec2 API.description: APIs for managing and utilizing ec2-style credentials
ec2 API.comment: May be required for some OpenStack features in non-keystone services

federation API.description: APIs for managing and consuming federated identity

identity API.description: APIs for managing user(s) and group(s) in a read/write identity store
identity API.comment: Some functionality for v2.0 is provided via the 'admin_crud' and 'user_crud' extensions

notifications.description: CADF notifications for events (authentication, creation of resources, etc)
notifications.comment: Highly recommended and may be required for some features of OpenStack

policy API.description: APIs for managing centralized policy.json distribution for OpenStack services

trust API.description: APIs for managing delegation (via trusts) of roles from one user/group to another user/group

resource API.description: APIs for managing resources (projects/tenants and/or domains)
resource API.comment: In the releases prior to Kilo this is covered by the assignment API

revoke API.comment: Highly recommended and required for Fernet (non-persistent) tokens

glance.guidance: Designated sections are the API implementation code and domain model.

stores.description: the swift, filesystem, and http stores

cinder.guidance: Designated sections are the API implementation code
cinder.comment: Historically, cinder has had plug-ins around schedulers and drivers.

api.description: API section means actually the CODE that exposes the API, not just API-comparability

drivers.comment: there MUST be requirements that it implements what's defined as core functionality in the Cinder API

scheduler.comment: there MUST be requirements that it implements what's defined as core functionality in the Cinder API

swift.guidance: Designated sections are proxy server, object server, container server, account server and select middleware
swift.comment: You should use the proxy and storage servers, and you can use your own DiskFile or add new middleware for the proxy or storage nodes.  Please review sections for specific middleware guidelines

proxy server.description: the proxy server code and, if enabled, the functionality implemented by provided middleware (eg static large objects or signed urls or bulk requests

object server.description: the object server code that calls a DiskFile implementation and updates container listings

container server.description: the code that provides a list of objects in a container and container metadata

account server.description: the code that provides a list of containers and account metadata

diskfile.description: the part of the object server that actually persists the object data to a storage volume

neutron.guidance: Not a core capability, no position at this time
neutron.comment: Neutron was not ready for review.

heat.guidance: Not a core capability, no position at this time

horizon.guidance: Not a core capability, no position at this time

ceilometer.guidance: Not a core capability, no position at this time

atomic.Description: Capabilities is unique and cannot be built out of other must-pass capabilities
atomic.name: Atomic

clients.Description: Candidates are widely used capabilities: Should be included if part of common libraries (Fog, Apache jclouds, etc)
clients.name: Used by Clients

complete.Description: Where the code being tested has a designated area of alternate implementation (extension framework) as per the Core Principles, there should be parity in capability tested across extension implementations. This also implies that the capability test is not configuration specific or locked to non-open technology
complete.name: Complete

deployed.Description: Candidates are widely deployed capabilities. We favor capabilities that are supported by multiple public cloud providers and private cloud products
deployed.name: Widely Deployed

discover.Description: Capability being tested is Service Discoverable (can be found in Keystone and via service introspection)
discover.name: Discoverable

doc.Description: Should be well documented, particularly the expected behavior. This can be a very subjective measure and we expect to refine this definition over time
doc.name: Documented

foundation.Description: Test capabilities that are required by other must-pass tests and/or depended on by many other capabilities
foundation.name: Foundation

future.Description: Should reflect future technical direction (from the project technical teams and the TC) and help manage deprecated capabilities
future.name: Future Direction

proximity.Description: Sometimes called a Test Cluster, selects for Capabilities that are related to Core Capabilities. This helps ensure that related capabilities are managed together
proximity.name: Proximity

stable.Description: Test is required stable for >2 releases because we don't want DefCore capabilities that do not have dependable APIs
stable.name: Stable

sticky.Description: A test that is a must-pass test should stay a must-pass test. This makes DefCore capabilities sticky release per release. Leaving Core is disruptive to the ecosystem
sticky.name: Core in Last Release

tools.Description: Candidates are widely used capabilities:Should be included if supported by common tools (RightScale, Scalr, CloudForms, ...)
tools.name: Used by Tools
